description: These episodes are designed to demystify the world of cryptography. One will hear about the different aspects of cryptography, associated terminology, different types of cryptography, applications to it and other topics ranging from the history of cryptography, to high-level concepts like ciphers and key exchanges. Discover practical applications of cryptography and how it is applied to various areas in the field of security.
name: Cryptography
subtitle: An in-depth look into cryptography concepts

episodes.title: Cryptography Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:01.373
[SOUND]
>> Hey everyone,

2
00:00:01.373 --> 00:00:06.321
wanted to take a minute to introduce
you to our Cryptography Series,

3
00:00:06.321 --> 00:00:10.005
Mike Rodrick here and
with me is Mr. Sean Oriyano.

4
00:00:10.005 --> 00:00:10.776
How you doing Sean?

5
00:00:10.776 --> 00:00:13.311
>> Doing pretty good today, Mike.

6
00:00:13.311 --> 00:00:14.671
How about you?
>> I'm doing fantastic.

7
00:00:14.671 --> 00:00:16.796
Looking forward to this.

8
00:00:16.796 --> 00:00:24.600
We are going to be spending the next week
covering Sean's book called Cryptography.

9
00:00:24.600 --> 00:00:26.710
So Sean, first of all, why this book?

10
00:00:26.710 --> 00:00:29.362
I know we got a lot of different
books out there that I can go and

11
00:00:29.362 --> 00:00:32.482
get about cryptography and other than
the fact that you wrote this one,

12
00:00:32.482 --> 00:00:34.000
[LAUGH] what makes this one so good?

13
00:00:34.000 --> 00:00:35.235
>> There you go.

14
00:00:35.235 --> 00:00:37.095
>> [LAUGH]
>> Or is there any other reason?

15
00:00:37.095 --> 00:00:38.975
[LAUGH]
>> Do you need another one?

16
00:00:38.975 --> 00:00:40.765
>> That's what I was thinking.

17
00:00:40.765 --> 00:00:42.671
[LAUGH]
>> Well,

18
00:00:42.671 --> 00:00:44.890
I've always had an interest
in cryptography.

19
00:00:44.890 --> 00:00:48.180
It's been something that's just
fascinated me since I was very young.

20
00:00:48.180 --> 00:00:51.060
When I set about writing this book,

21
00:00:51.060 --> 00:00:54.780
it comes on the heels of being
interested in this for years, but

22
00:00:54.780 --> 00:00:59.490
only seeing books that did beginning
stuff right in the first chapter or two,

23
00:00:59.490 --> 00:01:04.220
and then all of a sudden they're jumping
into all these abstract concepts.

24
00:01:04.220 --> 00:01:08.160
Now, someone jumping in new to
that is gonna have a problem.

25
00:01:08.160 --> 00:01:11.252
I mean, if you're an experienced person,
if you're, we joke around,

26
00:01:11.252 --> 00:01:14.120
a propeller head,
you understand mathematics and all that,

27
00:01:14.120 --> 00:01:18.300
then maybe you're gonna get, jumping
into the advanced stuff really quick.

28
00:01:18.300 --> 00:01:22.940
But I wanted something that was easily
understandable, dispensed with as many

29
00:01:22.940 --> 00:01:28.190
of the formulas as possible, which I
avoided putting any of them in there.

30
00:01:28.190 --> 00:01:30.960
I think there's like one or
two in there, that's about it.

31
00:01:30.960 --> 00:01:34.130
And so, I tried to make it accessible and
give examples and

32
00:01:34.130 --> 00:01:35.770
make it easy to understand.

33
00:01:35.770 --> 00:01:40.520
So in the end,
the result was a book that I'm proud of,

34
00:01:40.520 --> 00:01:43.890
that does make it easy,
does show examples, and

35
00:01:43.890 --> 00:01:49.410
makes it accessible to anybody that
is working with mathematics or not.

36
00:01:49.410 --> 00:01:53.270
Somebody that is in IT,
which this would be very useful for.

37
00:01:53.270 --> 00:01:57.500
A security person, anybody,
literally anybody, can read this book.

38
00:01:57.500 --> 00:02:01.350
>> So really not geared towards
any one person or one field.

39
00:02:01.350 --> 00:02:04.820
This is something that somebody that has
a little experience can pick up and enjoy.

40
00:02:04.820 --> 00:02:07.720
As well as somebody that had never
looked at cryptography before,

41
00:02:07.720 --> 00:02:10.710
could pick up this book and
really enjoy it and

42
00:02:10.710 --> 00:02:15.500
get a good understanding of that basic
foundation of knowledge on cryptography.

43
00:02:15.500 --> 00:02:16.210
>> Exactly.

44
00:02:16.210 --> 00:02:17.210
>> Fantastic.

45
00:02:17.210 --> 00:02:21.080
>> And from what I've heard from people
at Reddit, that's been the result, so

46
00:02:21.080 --> 00:02:22.110
I'm pretty happy about it.

47
00:02:22.110 --> 00:02:27.220
And I think it's just something that
can make a complex topic accessible.

48
00:02:27.220 --> 00:02:30.720
It's actually in the form of,
in some ways, almost like a puzzle book,

49
00:02:30.720 --> 00:02:32.110
so it can be fun.

50
00:02:32.110 --> 00:02:34.980
>> All right, so looking forward to it,
looking forward to it.

51
00:02:34.980 --> 00:02:38.990
So what kinda things are we gonna talk
about over the next week here in our show?

52
00:02:38.990 --> 00:02:41.920
>> Over the next week we
are gonna talk about all different

53
00:02:41.920 --> 00:02:43.120
aspects in cryptography.

54
00:02:43.120 --> 00:02:46.470
We'll talk some about the history
of cryptography, we'll talk about

55
00:02:46.470 --> 00:02:51.360
terminology, we will talk about classic
cryptography in the term of symmetric.

56
00:02:51.360 --> 00:02:55.360
We'll move to modern,
asymmetric cryptography examples, hashing,

57
00:02:55.360 --> 00:02:57.030
steganography.

58
00:02:57.030 --> 00:02:59.690
We'll talk about applications of it, and

59
00:02:59.690 --> 00:03:03.980
then we'll end stuff off with what
the future of cryptography looks like.

60
00:03:03.980 --> 00:03:07.740
When we get into some stuff that may
be kind of abstract in the form of

61
00:03:07.740 --> 00:03:11.712
quantum cryptography, and
that means quantum physics, so.

62
00:03:11.712 --> 00:03:14.702
>> [LAUGH].
>> So I'm giving you a chance to study and

63
00:03:14.702 --> 00:03:16.650
re-up on stuff, but
it's some exciting stuff.

64
00:03:16.650 --> 00:03:19.830
>> The whole spectrum of things
we're gonna see in here.

65
00:03:19.830 --> 00:03:20.680
>> Fantastic.

66
00:03:20.680 --> 00:03:23.227
Fantastic.
Well, I hope everybody out there is as

67
00:03:23.227 --> 00:03:26.570
excited as I am to get started
in the world of cryptography, so

68
00:03:26.570 --> 00:03:29.230
make sure you tune in and
check out our episodes.

69
00:03:29.230 --> 00:03:34.849
[MUSIC]
